cpa.games.board.oxo
Class OXOComputerPlayer

java.lang.Object
  |
  +--cpa.games.board.oxo.OXOPlayer
        |
        +--cpa.games.board.oxo.OXOComputerPlayer
All Implemented Interfaces:
BoardPlayer
public class OXOComputerPlayer
extends OXOPlayer

This class is a learning computer player for the OXO game.
Dedicated to smart An.

How it works

The OXOComputerPlayer keeps a record of all the situations it has encountered, what move was then played and what the result was: 'win', 'tie' or 'loss'. You can set the weights for a 'win', 'tie' and 'loss'. One of them must be 0 and one of them must be 1. The third one can then vary from 0 to 1. By default 'win' is set to 1, 'loss' is set to 0 and tie is set to 0.5. But you don't have to make it play to win (or at least not to loose). You could instruct the OXOComputerPlayer to play to loose, play for a tie, play to avoid a tie, ...

    You can also instruct the OXOComputerPlayer how to choose it's next move
  • HIGH: always take the best option (highest probability to win). In case of a tie, we choose at random.
  • RANDOM: pick one at random (in this case it doesn't take advantage of what it has learned, but it will certainly learn)
  • WEIGHTED: pick one at random, but taking into account the probability of winning. This is the default option.
You can set a minimal probability. Setting this higer then 0 will make the OXOComputerPlayer, from time to time, try a move that before has always resulted in a loss. This option only makes sense in case of WEIGHTED. A minimal probability of 1 will make WEIGHTED behaved like RANDOM.
You can also set the probability of an unknown move. By default it is 0.5, but you can set it to 1 for a highly adventures OXOComputerPlayer that seeks out new life, 0 for a extremely conservative OXOComputerPlayer or anything inbetween.

Website

http://www.schilduil.be/javadoc/cpa/games/board/oxo/OXOComputerPlayer.html
